The Evolution of Political Campaign Advertisements

About the project

Television advertising is ubiquitous with modern political campaigns in the United States. Consequently, televised advertisements have been the focal point of considerable research in political communication, psychology and behavior. Yet, despite considerable scholarship in these areas, we still know very little about political advertising prior to 1996, nor how political advertisements or the issues associated with them have evolved over time, the importance of which has been well recognized in the literature. Using an unprecedented collection of political ads beginning in 1912, this project will develop:

  • an automated system to identify issue and other politically relevant contents from ad image, audio and text
  • a state-of-the-art user interface that will give researchers the ability to query, interact with and download both low- and high-resolution videos
  • other outputs including automatically extracted features similar to those provided by existing ad collections
    •  

    We will use this research infrastructure to understand the evolution of issue advocacy, especially as it relates to consonance. The proposed research will be introduced at a conference and workshop that will take place at the end of the grant period. This outreach will ensure the infrastructure we develop is widely available to researchers and current ad data providers, while simultaneously providing an important interdisciplinary educational opportunity for graduate and undergraduate students.
